questions.text:
Which of the following are pro-apoptotic factors?
  1. BAK
  2. BAX
  3. BCL2
  4. BCL-XL
  5. MCL1
questions.solution:
BAK and BAX are pro-apoptotic factors, whereas BCL2, BCL-XL, and MCL1 are anti-apoptotic proteins.

Apoptosis, also known as programmed cell death, occurs due to the activation and release of certain proteases known as caspases. These enzymes are regulated by a balance between the actions of pro- apoptotic and anti-apoptotic proteins on the permeability of the mitochondrial membrane:

  • Pro-apoptotic proteins increase membrane permeability, thereby causing leakage of proteins that initiate apoptosis, like cytochrome c.
  • Anti-apoptotic proteins keep the membrane impermeable, preventing the release of cytochrome c.

There are two apoptotic pathways-

  • The intrinsic or mitochondrial pathway
  • Extrinsic or death-receptor initiated pathway

The intrinsic pathway is triggered by DNA damage, accumulation of misfolded proteins, and loss of survival signals. This leads to leakage of pro-apoptotic proteins like cytochrome c into the cytoplasm. Cytochrome c binds to APAF-1 (apoptosis-activating factor-1), forming an apoptosome. This complex activates caspase 9. 

The extrinsic pathway is triggered by the engagement of death receptors on the plasma membrane. It activates caspases 8 and 10. 

The active forms of these caspases activate executioner caspases (3 and 6), which act on various cell components to cause nuclear fragmentation, DNA degradation, etc. Cytoplasmic blebs and apoptotic bodies are then formed, which are ultimately phagocytosed.

questions.text: All of the following are true about disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) except:
questions.solution:
All of the following are true about disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) except for decreased prothrombin time (PT). In DIC, PT is typically prolonged.

DIC is a thrombohemorrhagic disorder occurring as a secondary complication in a variety of diseases. It is characterized by activation of the coagulation sequence that leads to the formation of microthrombi in the microcirculation of the body. 

As a result of microvascular thrombosis triggered by various causes, there is widespread deposition of fibrin in the circulation, causing vascular narrowing. This, in turn, activates fibrinolytic mechanisms via plasmin, resulting in decreased fibrin and increased fibrin degradation products (particularly D-dimers). Plasmin also consumes platelets and coagulation factors like factors V and VII, leading to decreased values of the same and subsequently prolonged PT and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT).

Some of the common presentations of DIC depending on the affected organs include:

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Dyspnea, cyanosis, respiratory failure
  • Convulsions, coma
  • Oliguria, acute renal failure
  • Circulatory failure, shock

DIC occurring in association with giant hemangiomas, where thrombi are formed within the neoplasm, is known as Kasabach-Merritt syndrome.

Management of DIC mainly involves treating the underlying cause.

As a consequence of the thrombotic diathesis, there is a consumption of platelets, fibrin, and coagulation factors and, secondarily, activation of fibrinolytic mechanisms.

questions.text:
A tall man presents with absent pubic and axillary hair, infantile genitalia, and high LH and FSH levels with XXY karyotype. What is the most probable diagnosis?

LH- Luteinizing hormone, FSH- Follicle-stimulating hormone
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is indicative of Klinefelter's syndrome (KS).

KS refers to male hypogonadism occurring when there are 2 or more X chromosomes and 1 or more Y chromosomes. The classic form of KS is associated with a 47 XXY karyotype, which occurs after meiotic nondisjunction of the sex chromosomes during gametogenesis.

KS is characterized by:

  • Small atrophied testes with a small penis
  • Hypogonadism
  • Male infertility
  • Tall stature or increased leg length
  • Gynecomastia
  • Loss of secondary sexual characteristics like a deep voice and male facial and pubic hair distribution

Patients are at risk for type 2 diabetes and metabolic syndrome (due to increased insulin resistance), congenital cardiac anomalies like mitral valve prolapse, atrial and ventricular septal defects, osteoporosis (due to sex hormone imbalances), breast cancer, and autoimmune diseases like SLE.

Plasma concentrations of FSH, LH, and estradiol are increased and plasma testosterone are decreased.

Other options:

Option A. Vanishing testis syndrome is testicular atrophy occurring due to persistent stimulation by high FSH levels. In severe cases, there is complete regression of the testis; hence, the name, vanishing testis. A normal karyotype (46 XY) is seen in these individuals.

Option C. Fragile X syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability in males, occuring due to a trinucleotide expansion mutation in the familial mental retardation 1 gene. The most characteristic physical feature is macro-orchidism, that is, large testicles. They also have a long face with a large mandible and large everted ears.

Option D. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is a group of autosomal recessive disorders, most commonly occurring due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. This causes a block in steroid production, resulting in increased ACTH secretion and excess androgens. Thus, these patients present with bilateral adrenal hyperplasia, virilism (masculinization in females and precocious puberty in males), and salt wasting syndrome.

questions.text:
Arrange the following cellular events of inflammation in the correct sequence:
  1. Rolling
  2. Cytokine-mediated integrin activation
  3. Adhesion
  4. Migration
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of cellular events that occurs during inflammation is as follows: Rolling, Cytokine-mediated integrin activation, Adhesion, Migration.

The recruitment of leucocytes to the site of inflammation is a multi-step process that is mediated by adhesion molecules and cytokines called chemokines. This process can be divided into sequential phases:

  1. In the lumen: margination, rolling and adhesion to the endothelium occurs.
  2. Migration of the leucocytes across the endothelium and vessel wall
  3. Migration in the tissues towards a chemotactic stimulus.

The process of leucocyte recruitment is as follows:

  • Margination: Because of the dilation of the inflamed postcapillary venues, there is stasis of blood flow, and hence, more leucocytes assume a peripheral position along the endothelial surface; this process of leucocyte redistribution is called margination.
  • Rolling: The slowed down leucocytes then sense the signals from the endothelium and start rolling on the vessel wall.
  • Cytokine-mediated integrin activation: The attachment of leucocytes to the endothelial cells requires adhesion molecules that are activated by cytokines. The major families of proteins involved in adhesion and migration are selectins and integrins and their ligands.
  • Adhesions: The weak rolling interactions slow down the leucocytes and allow them to bind more firmly to the endothelium. Chemokines that were produced at the site of injury bind to the endothelial cell proteoglycans. These chemokines then bind to the rolling leucocytes and activate them. This, in turn, converts the ligands for β1 and β2 integrins, VLA-4, and LFA-1 present on the leucocytes to a high-affinity state.
  • This combination of cytokine-induced expression of integrin ligands on the endothelium and increased integrin affinity on the leucocytes leads to firm adhesion of leucocytes to the endothelium at the site of inflammation.
  • Leucocyte migration: This is the movement of leucocytes through the intact endothelium, called transmigration or diapedesis. This occurs in postcapillary venules. This migration occurs through the inter-endothelial gap towards the chemical concentration gradient created by the chemokines at the site of injury. This occurs with the help of adhesion molecules present in the intercellular junctions such as platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule (PECAM-1) or CD31.

questions.text: Which cytokine activates macrophages via the classical pathway?
questions.solution:
IFN-Ɣ activates macrophages via the classical pathway.

Macrophages are involved in chronic inflammatory reactions, where they secrete cytokines and growth factors that eliminate microbes and damaged tissues and activate T lymphocytes. They are also involved in tissue repair. Macrophages are activated via two pathways:

  • Classical pathway: In this pathway, macrophages are activated by cytokine IFN-Ɣ secreted by Th1 cells, microbial products (endotoxin), T cell-derived signals, or foreign substances. These macrophages play an important role in host defense and inflammatory reactions. 
  • Alternate pathway: In this pathway, macrophages are activated by cytokines like IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 (options B & C) secreted by Th2 cells. These macrophages are primarily involved in tissue repair. 

T-lymphocytes and macrophages show a bidirectional interaction, where lymphocytes produce cytokines that activate macrophages and activated macrophages produce cytokines to stimulate T-lymphocyte responses.

Other options:

Option D: IL-17 is produced by Th17 cells and secrete chemokines responsible for neutrophil recruitment.

A 5-year-old boy was brought by his parents to screen for thalassemia since both his parents are carriers of the disease. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) was performed, and the result is given below. What is the diagnosis?

X-axis: Time (in min)

The HPLC results show increased HbA2 and normal HbF values, pointing to a diagnosis of thalassemia trait.

β-thalassemia occurs due to mutations causing an impaired synthesis of β-globin chains of hemoglobin (Hb), leading to anemia, hypoxia, and hemolysis. The mutations can be of two types:

  1. Absent β chain synthesis (β0)
  2. Reduced β chain synthesis (β+)

Major: 

  • Severe microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells (typical Hb: 3 to 6 g/dL), requiring regular blood transfusions
  • Crewcut appearance of facial bones and skull (due to cortical bone erosion by expanding marrow and new bone formation)
  • Speen, liver, and lymph node enlargement (due to extramedullary hematopoiesis)

Minor: 

  • More common
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Mild microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells and basophilic stippling (important to rule out iron deficiency anemia by serum iron studies)
  • Mild erythroid hyperplasia in bone marrow

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby boy had recurrent episodes of bacterial infection. There is also a history of bloody diarrhoea and eczema during the first month of life. Peripheral smear showed abnormally small-sized platelets. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome.

Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive disease characterized by thrombocytopenia and small-sized platelets. Patients often present in infancy with bruising, bloody diarrhea, eczema, and susceptibility to recurrent infections. It occurs due to mutations in the gene located at Xp11.23 that encodes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP).

Along with microthrombocytopenia, peripheral smear shows loss of T lymphocytes. Patients are also unable to produce antibodies to antigens, thereby making them immunocompromised. As a result, there is also an increased risk of autoimmune disorders and cancers like B-cell lymphomas.

Splenectomy improves platelet counts in these patients since increased platelet destruction in the spleen is prevented. However, the only definitive treatment is hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

Other options:

Option A: Glanzmann's thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive condition due to a defect in IIb/IIIa leading to defective platelet aggregation.

Option B: Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is a condition characterized by low platelet count due to autoantibody-mediated destruction. Patients present with easy bruising, nosebleeds, gingival bleeding, and bleeding into the skin and soft tissues. Laboratory findings typically show isolated thrombocytopenia.

Option C: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition occurring due to defective adhesion of platelets to the subendothelial extracellular matrix. It is due to a deficiency of the glycoprotein complex Ib–IX on the platelet membrane. Patients often present with bleeding tendencies.

Related Pearl: Causes of Thrombocytopenia

I. Decreased Production of Platelets

  1. Selective impairment of platelet production
    • Drug-induced: alcohol, thiazides, cytotoxic drugs
    • Infections: measles, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
  2. Nutritional deficiencies - B12, folate deficiency
  3. Bone marrow failure - aplastic anemia
  4. Bone marrow replacement - leukemia, disseminated cancer, granulomatous disease
  5. Ineffective hematopoiesis - myelodysplastic syndromes 

II. Decreased Platelet Survival

  1. Immunologic destruction
    • Primary autoimmune - chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura, acute immune thrombocytopenic purpura
    • Secondary autoimmune - systemic lupus erythematosus, B-cell lymphoid neoplasms
    • Alloimmune - posttransfusion and neonatal
    • Drug-associated - quinidine, heparin, sulfa compounds
    • Infections - HIV, infectious mononucleosis (transient, mild), dengue fever
  2. Nonimmunologic destruction
    • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
    • Thrombotic microangiopathies
    • Giant hemangiomas

III. Sequestration - The spleen normally sequesters 30% to 35% of platelets. This can rise to 80% to 90% when the spleen is enlarged, producing moderate degrees of thrombocytopenia.

IV. Dilution - Transfusions

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presented with a history of lymph node enlargement in his neck and axillae for the past 3 weeks. Investigations revealed mild anemia with leukocytosis of 40,000/mm3. The peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). CLL is a tumor of mature B cells and the most common leukemia in adults.

Patients with CLL present with nonspecific symptoms like easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are present in about 50-60% of cases. There is also increased susceptibility to infections due to disruption of immune processes.

The peripheral smear, as shown in the image below, typically shows small round lymphocytes with condensed chromatin and scant cytoplasm (indicated by arrows). Some of these cells get disrupted while preparing the smear; these cells are called smudge cells (indicated by arrowheads).

 

Microscopy of the lymph nodes shows diffuse effacement of the architecture by small lymphocytes. Some larger, activated lymphocytes are also present. They often gather in loose aggregates, referred to as proliferation centers. They contain mitotically active cells. When present, such proliferation centers are pathognomonic for CLL.

Other options:

Option A: Acute lymphoblastic lymphoma (ALL) is a tumor of immature B or T cells and the most common leukemia in children. The peripheral blood smear shows lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, and scant agranular cytoplasm.

Option C: Multiple myeloma is a neoplasm of plasma cells. It is also typically associated with punched-out bony lesions, hypercalcemia, and renal failure. Bone marrow aspirate shows plasma cells with multiple nuclei and prominent nucleoli. Serum protein electrophoresis shows a spike of M protein (monoclonal immunoglobulin).

Option D: Waldenström macroglobulinemia is a hyperviscosity syndrome caused due to excess amounts of monoclonal IgM secreted by plasma cells. It is a type of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, with bone marrow aspirate showing small lymphocytes with variable degrees of plasma differentiation.

questions.solution:
Mantle cell lymphoma is associated with the expression of all of the given options except CD23.

Mantle cell lymphoma is a rare lymphoid tumor that shows an (11;14) translocation. This causes overexpression of cyclin D1, which in turn enhances the progression of the G1-phase to the S-phase during the cell cycle. Furthermore, mantle cell lymphoma is also associated with high levels of expression of CD19, CD20, and surface Ig. It is usually CD5+ and CD23−, which distinguishes it from chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).

The small homogenous neoplastic lymphoid cells in mantle cell lymphoma surround an atrophic germinal center, resembling normal mantle zone B cells. These neoplastic cells have irregular nuclear outlines, condensed chromatin, and scant cytoplasm. Large cells resembling prolymphocytes and centroblasts are absent, distinguishing mantle cell lymphoma from CLL and follicular lymphoma, respectively.

Patients commonly present with painless lymphadenopathy and involvement of the spleen, liver, gut, and bone marrow. Mantle cell lymphoma is an aggressive incurable tumor with a median survival of 8-10 years.

questions.text: A 60 year-old-woman comes with complaints of sudden onset blindness of the right eye, with throbbing headache in the right temporal region associated with jaw claudication. On examination, a thickened tender cord-like structure can be felt in the temple. Temporal artery biopsy shows the following. Which among the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: Lesions are distributed throughout the entire length of the artery
Classic lesions exhibit medial granulomatous inflammation
T cell infiltrates are predominantly CD8+
Fragmentation is seen in external elastic lamina

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histology image is suggestive of giant cell/temporal arteritis. Classic lesions exhibit medial granulomatous inflammation.

Giant cell/temporal arteritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder of large to small-sized arteries that especially affects the arteries of the head. It is seen in people over 50 years of age.

It can affect the following arteries:

  • Superficial temporal artery: Intense facial pain or headache along the course of the artery
  • Ophthalmic arteries: Sudden and permanent diplopia or blindness
  • Aorta: Giant-cell aortitis
  • Vertebral arteries

A biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis. However, a negative biopsy cannot exclude the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis because the lesions are focally distributed, leaving long segments of the artery normal. Hence, the biopsy sample may be taken from the normal part of the artery, leading to a false-negative report. For the same reason, an adequate biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment.

Biopsy findings of giant cell arteritis include:

  • Classic lesions are primarily medial granulomatous inflammation.
  • These lesions involve the internal elastic lamina, leading to elastic lamina fragmentation.
  • There is intimal thickening that reduces the luminal diameter.
  • There is an infiltrate with T cells (CD4+ > CD8+), macrophages, and multinucleated giant cells (75% of specimens).

The image below shows giant cell arteritis with intimal thickening and internal elastic lamina fragmentation:

 

Corticosteroids and anti-TNF therapies are used for treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of saccular aneurysms?

choices.text: Migration of smooth muscle into the sac
Absence of intimal elastic lamina in the sac
Deposition of mucoid material in the media
Low-grade inflammation of the vessel wall

questions.solution:
The true statement about the pathogenesis of saccular aneurysms is the absence of intimal elastic interna in the sac.

Saccular (or berry) aneurysm is the most common type of intracranial aneurysm, most often occurring in the anterior circulation of the circle of Willis. Rupture of this aneurysm is the most common cause of spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage.

The following factors are implicated in the pathogenesis of saccular aneurysm:

  • Genetic factors: Increased incidence in first-degree relatives
  • Associated syndromes: Increased incidence in individuals with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, neurofibromatosis type 1, Marfan syndrome, etc
  • Predisposing factors: Increased incidence in cigarette smokers and individuals with hypertension

The aneurysmal sac is made up of thickened hyalinized intima and a covering of adventitia. The absence of smooth muscle and intimal elastic lamina in the sac suggests that these aneurysms are developmental anomalies. Atheromatous plaques, calcification, thrombi, or prior hemorrhage may be present within the aneurysm.  

Rupture usually occurs at the apex of the sac. It is often associated with a sudden increase in intracranial pressure, such as when straining during defecation or sexual stimulation. Patients complain of an acute excruciating headache and loss of consciousness. The prognosis worsens with each episode.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions is/are not associated with secondary Raynaud phenomenon?
  1. Systemic lupus erythematosus
  2. Scleroderma
  3. Buerger disease
  4. Raynaud's disease
  5. Atherosclerosis
questions.solution:
The option not associated with secondary Raynaud's phenomenon is raynaud’s disease, as it is the primary raynaud's phenomenon, and all others are associated with secondary raynaud's phenomenon.

Raynaud's phenomenon refers to exaggerated vasoconstriction of arteries and arterioles in the extremities, particularly the fingers and toes, but also occasionally the nose, earlobes, or lips. Raynaud's phenomenon can be a primary entity or secondary to other disorders.

Mechanism of raynaud's phenomenon - Restricted blood flow induces paroxysmal pallor, and even cyanosis in severe cases. The involved digits classically show red, white, and blue color changes from the most proximal to the most distal regions. This correlates with proximal vasodilation, central vasoconstriction, and more distal cyanosis.

Raynaud's disease (primary raynaud's phenomenon) is however diagnosed when all the secondary causes of raynaud's phenomenon have been ruled out. It accounts for more than 50% of cases and is more prevalent in women, affecting them about five times more frequently than men. Symptoms typically begin between the ages of 20 and 40 years, with the fingers being more commonly affected than the toes.

questions.text: A 21-year-old previously healthy athlete suffers a sudden cardiac arrest while playing a sport. On autopsy, it was found that there was hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The gene encoding for which of the following proteins is most commonly mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The gene encoding for β-myosin heavy chain (β-MHC) proteins is most commonly mutated in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

HCM is a common autosomal dominant disorder characterized by myocardial hypertrophy, abnormal diastolic filling (with preserved systolic function), and intermittent left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. It is the leading cause of unexplained left ventricular hypertrophy.

It is caused by mutations in genes that encode sarcomeric proteins, including myosin-binding protein C (MYBP-C) and β-MHC (MYH7). It can also rarely occur due to mutations in genes coding for cardiac TnI, TnT, and α-tropomyosin.

In HCM, myocardial hypertrophy occurs without ventricular dilation. Furthermore, there is asymmetric septal hypertrophy, where the ventricular septum is disproportionately thickened compared to the left ventricular free wall. The enlarged septum bulges into the ventricular cavity, giving it a banana-like shape. Hypertrophy is most marked in the subaortic region of the septum.

The most important histologic features in HCM are:

  • Massive myocyte hypertrophy
  • Myofiber disarray including that of myocyte bundles, individual myocytes, and contractile elements
  • Fibrotic narrowing of small intramural arteries
  • Interstitial and replacement fibrosis

The images below show normal cardiac myocytes and myofibril disarray in HCM, respectively:

 

Exertional dyspnea due to reduced cardiac output is seen, and a harsh systolic ejection murmur caused due to LVOT obstruction can be heard. Further, atrial fibrillation, stroke due to mural thrombus formation, and ventricular arrhythmias are common complications of HCM. 

β-adrenergic blockers can be used to decrease heart rate and contractility, and implantable cardioverter defibrillators are used for patients with ventricular arrhythmias.

Other options:

Option A: Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) occurs due to truncating mutations in the titin gene. The heart in DCM is flabby and hypo-contracting, in contrast with the thick-walled, heavy, and hyper-contracting heart in HCM. Histology reveals hypertrophied myocytes with hyperchromatic distorted nuclei with a ninja star-like appearance, as shown in the image below. Variable degrees of interstitial and endocardial fibrosis is also present.

Option C: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) is an autosomal dominant disorder that occurs due to mutations of genes encoding desmosomal junctional proteins. It typically manifests as right-sided heart failure and can cause sudden cardiac death. Histology shows loss of myocytes, fatty infiltration, and focal fibrosis.

Option D: HCM occurs due to mutations in the gene encoding α-tropomyosin. However, this is rare, and HCM occurs most commonly due to mutations in genes encoding myosin-binding protein C (MYBP-C) and β-MHC (MYH7).

questions.text:
A patient with a family history of Alport syndrome comes for genetic counseling. Which of the following inheritance patterns can be seen in Alport syndrome?
  1. X-linked dominant
  2. Mitochondrial
  3. Autosomal dominant
  4. Autosomal recessive
questions.solution:
The inheritance patterns seen in Alport syndrome are X-linked dominant, autosomal dominant, and autosomal recessive.

Alport syndrome is a form of hereditary nephritis caused by a mutation in the gene encoding type IV collagen. The most common inheritance pattern is X-linked dominant, wherein all males develop the full syndrome but women present with only hematuria. Other rare patterns include autosomal dominant and autosomal recessive, wherein both males and females develop the full spectrum.

Type IV collagen is essential for the functioning of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), the lens of the eye, and the cochlea. Thus, patients most commonly present with hematuria, which progresses to chronic renal failure. Various eye disorders, including lens dislocation, posterior cataracts, corneal dystrophy, and nerve deafness may also be present. 

Electron microscopy shows irregular thickening and thinning of the GBM, with marked splitting and lamination of the lamina densa, giving it a typical basket-weave appearance.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with a bulky scrotal swelling. On resection, the testicular mass is found to be homogenous, grey-white, and does not show hemorrhage or necrosis. The histopathological image is shown below. Which of the following is true for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histological image is suggestive of seminoma of the testes, and human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) levels may be elevated.

"Classic" or "typical" seminomas are the most common type of germ cell tumor. They are bulky, homogenous, pale, and well-circumscribed masses that do not show any hemorrhage or necrosis, as shown in the image below. 

Microscopically, sheets of uniform tumor cells divided into poorly demarcated lobules by fibrous septa are seen. Each cell is large, round, and has a distinct cell membrane, abundant clear cytoplasm, and a large central nucleus with a few nucleoli.

In about 15% of cases, serum HCG levels are raised as these seminomas contain syncytiotrophoblasts. Lactate dehdrogenase (LDH) levels are also measured to assess tumor burden.

Therapy depends on the stage of the tumor. Seminoma has the best prognosis. Most cases of seminoma stages I and II can be cured by orchiectomy with or without chemotherapy or radiotherapy.

Other options:

Option B: ɑ-fetoprotein (AFP) levels are elevated in yolk sac tumors.

Options C and D: Seminoma cells stain positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and podoplanin and negative for cytokeratin by immunohistochemistry.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presented with abdominal pain and melena. On endoscopy, a bleeding gastric mass with irregular borders was identified along the greater curvature of the stomach. Microscopy is as shown in the image below. Which of the following is a specific marker for the tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histological picture showing spindle-shaped tumor cells are suggestive of gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST), for which CD 117 is the specific marker. 

GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, with the most common site being the stomach. The tumor arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal or pacemaker cells of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria.

Most GISTs occur due to gain-of-function mutations in receptor tyrosine kinase KIT (~75%) or PDGRF-ɑ (~8%). 

The tumor peaks at 60 years of age. It is often associated with the Carney triad, a nonhereditary condition characterized by GIST, paraganglioma, and pulmonary chondroma. GIST also has a higher incidence in individuals with neurofibromatosis I.

Patients typically present with anemia (due to blood loss caused by mucosal ulceration) and symptoms of mass effect. However, GISTs may also be discovered incidentally during imaging or surgery.

Microscopically, GIST can be of two patterns:

  1. Spindle cell type: The tumor is composed of thin elongated cells.
  2. Epitheloid type: The tumor is composed of plump epithelial-like cells.

Mixed patterns may also be seen.

The most useful immunohistochemical marker is KIT (CD117) detectable in Cajal cells, along with DOG1.

The prognosis depends on tumor size, mitotic index, and location (GISTs arising in the stomach are less aggressive than those arising in the small intestine). Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents to the outpatient department with fever, epigastric discomfort, progressive weight loss, arthralgia, and foul-smelling diarrhea for the past 6 months. There is no relation between the abdominal pain and his bowel movements. He was started on a restrictive diet, which showed no improvement. His biopsy is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is whipple disease which is caused by a gram-positive actinomycete, named Tropheryma whipplei.

Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by a gram-positive bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It presents as 

  • Diarrhea
  • Steatorrhea due to malabsorption caused by impaired lymphatic transport.
  • Weight loss
  • Arthralgia
  • Central nervous system problems
  • Cardiac problems

The morphologic hallmark of whipple disease is a dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria. Macrophages contain periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant granules that represent lysosomes stuffed with partially digested bacteria.

Other options:

Option A: Irritable bowel syndrome presents with recurrent abdominal pain that may be - 

  • related to defecation
  • associated with a change in frequency 
  • associated with a change in appearance

Despite having these symptoms, the endoscopy and microscopic examination are normal in patients with irritable bowel syndrome.

Option C: Cystic fibrosis is a congenital disorder due to a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene located on chromosome 7. It leads to abnormal transport of chloride and bicarbonate ions in the lungs, gastrointestinal tract, pancreas and reproductive tract. It presents as

  • Lungs - recurrent respiratory infections. 
  • Pancreas - exocrine pancreatic insufficiency causing fat malabsorption and steatorrhoea. 
  • Reproductive tract - infertility due to absent vas deferens.

Option D: Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten-induced enteropathy where there is an excessive inflammatory response to gluten and its breakdown product, gliadin. This leads to inflammatory infiltration of the lamina propria which subsequently impairs various nutrient absorption.

Clinically, it presents as a malabsorption syndrome with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and marked weight loss. Microscopic findings show

  • Villi atrophy
  • Villi flattening
  • Crypt hyperplasia
  • Increased intraepithelial T lymphocytes

Symptoms usually subside with a gluten restricted diet.

questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with fever and breathlessness. He has been on antiretroviral therapy for the past 2 weeks and his  CD4 count is 45 cells/cu mm. Imaging shows a lesion in the middle lobe of the lung.  The lung biopsy shows the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical details and the characteristic histological image is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia. The image shows a cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion seperated from the nuclear membrane by a halo (owl’s eye appearance). Within the cytoplasm of infected cells, smaller basophilic inclusions can also be seen

CMV causes an asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like infection in healthy individuals but devastating systemic infections in neonates and in immunocompromised people. In healthy individuals, acute CMV infection induces transient but severe immunosuppression by infecting dendritic cells which causes impairment of antigen processing and T cell stimulation. In immunosuppressed individuals (e.g., transplant recipients, HIV- infected individuals), serious, disseminated CMV infections primarily affect the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (gastritis and colitis).

Other options:

Option A: Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia is seen as a response to infection or inflammation to the lungs by virus, bacteria, inhaled toxins and drugs. Histologically COP is characterized by the presence of Masson bodies. These are polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within alveolar ducts, alveoli and bronchioles along with foci of fibrosis. Patients present with cough and dyspnea and have patchy subpleural or peribronchial areas of consolidation radiographically.

Image showing alveolar spaces filled with balls of fibroblasts (Masson bodies).


Option C: Cryptococcal pneumonia is a fungal infection caused by cryptococcus neoformans predominantly in immunosuppressed individuals and rarely in the immunocompetent population. Pulmonary cryptococcosis in AIDS/immunosuppressed patients presents as an interstitial lung disease with lymph node enlargement. The histopathological diagnosis is made by identifying encapsulated yeast forms within sections of the inflammatory lung tissue.

Option D: Giant cell pneumonia is a fatal but rare complication of measles, which is seen in children with immunodeficiency or severe malnutrition. The lymphoid organs, lungs and sputum typically show multinucleate giant cells, called Warthin-Finkeldey cells, which have eosinophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies.

The image below shows Warthin–Finkeldey giant cell with large grapelike clusters of inclusion bodies.

questions.text:
Match the following microscopic findings to the disease conditions in which they are seen.
Microscopic findings Lung disease
1. Coal-laden macrophages  A. Silicosis
2. Golden-brown fusiform rods  B. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
3. Non-necrotizing granulomas  C. Anthracosis
4. Nodules of whorled collagen fibers D. Asbestosis
questions.solution:
The correct match is Option 2: 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A.

Anthracosis/ coal workers' pneumoconiosis is a pulmonary condition seen in coal miners. It is caused due to the phagocytosis of the inhaled carbonaceous pigment by the alveolar or interstitial macrophages and its subsequent accumulation in the connective tissue spaces. With continued exposure, lung tissue undergoes progressive massive fibrosis. The upper lobes and upper zones of the lower lobes of the lungs are commonly involved.

Microscopic features consist of coal-laden macrophages, black pigment, and dense collagenous interstitial fibrosis (in advanced stages), as shown in the image below.

 

Asbestosis occurs due to the inhalation of crystalline hydrated silicates (asbestos). It is characterized by diffuse parenchymal interstitial fibrosis. It usually begins in the lower lobes of the lungs. Other asbestos-related diseases include pleural plaques, recurrent pleural effusions, lung carcinoma, and mesothelioma.

Hallmark microscopic findings are golden brown, fusiform or beaded rods called asbestos bodies, as shown in the image below. These are formed when the asbestos fibers phagocytosed by the macrophages are coated by iron-containing proteinaceous material derived from phagocyte ferritin. Pleural plaques of dense collagen that may be calcified are the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure. They involve the anterior and posterolateral aspects of the parietal pleura and the diaphragmatic domes.

 

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is an immunologically mediated granulomatous disease that occurs in response to continuous exposure to inhaled organic antigens (mold, hay dust, bird proteins, thermophilic bacteria in air-conditioning units). Pathological changes in response to such exposures are mediated by the CD4+ and CD8+ T-lymphocytes (type IV hypersensitivity reactions) and proinflammatory chemokines.

Microscopic findings include interstitial pneumonitis (lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages) and non-necrotizing granulomas, as shown in the image below. Chronic disease gives rise to obliterative bronchiolitis and honeycombing.

 

Silicosis occurs due to inhalation of crystalline silicon dioxide (silica) as seen in individuals employed in concrete work and sandblasting. Macrophages incorporate inhaled silica particles, thereby activating and releasing inflammatory mediators (IL-1, IL-8) that cause fibroblast recruitment. Subsequently, collagen is deposited in the interstitium. Upper lung zones and hilar lymph nodes are commonly involved.

Microscopy reveals coalescent nodules of whorled collagen fibers surrounded by a peripheral zone of silica-laden macrophages, as shown in the image below. As the disease progresses, these nodules coalesce into scars. Sometimes, thin sheets of calcification can occur in hilar lymph nodes, giving an eggshell appearance.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with a history of diffuse thyroid swelling for the past 2 months. Investigations show increased T3 and T4 levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. She undergoes fine needle aspiration cytology which is shown in the image below. Which of the following findings are seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hashitoxicosis, a transient phase of thyrotoxicosis that usually occurs in the first two months of Hashimoto thyroiditis, and Hürthle cells are seen in fine-needle aspiration in this condition.

Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease characterized by the gradual destruction of the thyroid gland leading to thyroid failure. It is more commonly seen in females between 45 to 65 years of age. In the majority of cases, it is caused by the presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase.

Morphologically, there is a diffuse and symmetrical enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. Microscopic features include:

  • Extensive lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well-developed germinal centers
  • Hürthle cells, are epithelial cells that line atrophied thyroid follicles and contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm

The image below shows a histopathological picture of Hashimoto's thyroiditis:

In most cases, there is a gradual development of hypothyroidism. However, in some patients, transient thyrotoxicosis may occur due to the release of thyroid hormones from disrupted thyroid follicles known as hashitoxicosis. Free T4 and T3 levels are elevated and TSH and radioactive iodine uptake are decreased in this phase. As hypothyroidism occurs, T4 and T3 levels fall, and TSH increases. Patients are also more susceptible to developing other autoimmune diseases like type 1 diabetes and systemic lupus erythematosus.  

Other options:

Options B and C: Orphan Annie Eye nuclei (nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin and a ground-glass appearance) and pseudo-inclusions (nuclear membrane grooves) are characteristic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, which is the most common form of thyroid cancer. Other histological hallmarks include branching papillae covered by a single to multiple layers of cuboidal epithelial cell and psammoma bodies (concentrically calcified structures within the papillae). This type of cancer has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in 95% of cases.

Option D. Multinucleate giant cells are found in granulomatous thyroiditis. Granulomatous thyroiditis, also known as De Quervain thyroiditis, occurs due to viral infection, most often upper respiratory tract infection. The virus destroys thyroid follicles, inciting cytotoxic T lymphocyte reaction against the thyroid antigens. Thyroid pain is the most common symptom. In some cases, there may be transient thyrotoxicosis lasting for 2-6 weeks. Normal function returns after recovery.

questions.text: What is the underlying pathology in patients with Conn's syndrome?
questions.solution:
The underlying pathology in patients with Conn's syndrome is adrenal adenoma.

Hyperaldosteronism may be primary or secondary. 

Primary hyperaldosteronism is due to autonomous overproduction of aldosterone with resultant suppression of RAAS. It can occur due to adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma. It presents with the following features:

  • Hypertension (most common)
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Polyuria (due to ANP)
  • Polydipsia (due to polyuria)
  • Muscle weakness

It is confirmed by elevated ratios of plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity (PAC / PRA).

When primary hyperaldosteronism is due to an aldosterone-secreting adenoma, it is called Conn syndrome. Patients are usually treated with spironolactone followed by surgical removal of adenoma. In patients treated with spironolactone, the adenomas contain eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions called spironolactone bodies.

In secondary hyperaldosteronism, aldosterone release occurs in response to the activation of the renin-angiotensin system (RAAS).

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presented with a large, rapidly growing painless breast lump. On examination, a smooth, multinodular breast lump was noticed. Microscopic examination of the core biopsy sample is shown below. Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding this condition?

choices.text: Stromal cellularity is increased next to the epithelium
Absence of epithelial elements suggests malignancy
Both epithelial and stromal components can metastasize

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image are suggestive of phyllodes tumor. Here, only the stromal component is involved in metastasis. 

Phyllodes tumor is a fibroepithelial tumor arising from the intralobular stroma. It presents as a smooth, rapidly growing, multinodular, painless breast lump that is usually palpable. It most commonly presents in the 6th decade of life and is associated with:

  • Gain in chromosome 1q
  • HOXB13 overexpression

Phyllodes tumors show stromal cellularity next to the epithelium (subepithelial or periepithelial regions). This feature helps to differentiate it from intracanalicular fibroadenoma.

The prognosis of phyllodes tumors depends on their histological grade. Most phyllodes tumors are low grade, with limited stromal cellularity. They recur only occasionally and do not metastasize.

The features of malignant (intermediate and high grade) phyllodes tumors are:

  • Markedly increased stromal cellularity
  • Stromal overgrowth - absence of epithelial elements 
  • Nuclear atypia
  • Increased mitosis (>10/ 10 hpf) 
  • Highly recurrent

Regardless of the grade, lymphatic spread is rare in phyllodes tumors. Hence, axillary lymph node dissection is contraindicated.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is caused by trinucleotide-repeat mutations in the coding region of the gene?
questions.solution:
Huntington's disease (HD) is caused by trinucleotide-repeat mutations (CAG) in the coding region of the gene.

HD is an autosomal dominant condition occurring due to the degeneration of striatal neurons. Patients typically present with progressive chorea, that is, jerky, hyperkinetic, dystonic movements involving all parts of the body, and dementia. They may also develop bradykinesia and rigidity. A direct relationship exists between the degree of striatal degeneration and the severity of clinical symptoms.

The caudate nucleus and putamen are atrophied, and the lateral and third ventricles are dilated. The frontal lobe is also frequently atrophied. On microscopy, loss of striatal neurons is most marked in the caudate nucleus. Intranuclear inclusions of the defective protein huntingtin can be seen in striatal and cerebral cortex neurons.

HD is a progressive and fatal disease, with a clinical course of 15 years and no effective therapy. The most common cause of death is pneumonia, occurring in advanced stages.

Other diseases that affect the coding region of the gene include:

  • Spinobulbar muscular atrophy (Kennedy disease)
  • Spinocerebellar ataxias
  • Dentatorubral-pallidoluysian atrophy (Haw–River syndrome)

Other options:

Options B, C, and D: Myotonic dystrophy, Friedreich ataxia, and Fragile X syndrome are disorders caused by trinucleotide-repeat mutations in the non coding region of the gene.

questions.text: An autopsy of a 38-year-old male patient who died of cardiac failure showed the following histopathological image of the endocardium. Which of the following best describes the form of vegetation found in this condition?

choices.text: Small, warty vegetations along the line of closure of the valve leaflets
Large, irregular masses on valve cusps and chordae
Small, bland vegetations on the line of closure
Small to medium sized vegetations on either sides of the valve

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with histopathology showing Anitschkow cells and Aschoff bodies are pathognomic of the rheumatic fever (RF) phase of rheumatic heart disease (RHD). It is associated with small, warty vegetations along the lines of closure of the valve leaflets.

RF is an acute, immunologically mediated, multisystem inflammatory disease classically occurring a few weeks after group A streptococcal pharyngitis. RHD is principally characterized by deforming fibrotic valvular disease, particularly the mitral valve.

Important pathological findings in rheumatic fever are:

  • Inflammation in the three layers of the heart can result in endocarditis, myocarditis, pericarditis, or pancarditis.
  • Inflammation of the endocardium and the left side valves can lead to fibrinoid necrosis. Over these areas of necrosis, small vegetations can be seen along the lines of closure, called verrucae.
  • In the subendocardium, irregular thickenings called MacCallum plaques can be present.
  • Aschoff bodies are collections of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), scattered plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages (called Anitschkow cells). The Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence they are also called caterpillar cells.
  • Mitral valve in chronic RHD shows leaflet thickening, commissural fusion and shortening, and thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords.This leads to narrowing of the mitral orifice, giving it a fish mouth appearance.

questions.text:
A patient presents with a sudden high-grade fever associated with chills and a productive cough for the past 3 days. A chest x-ray is taken which is shown below. The sputum is sent for culture and sensitivity. Arrange the following histopathological changes in the sequence of appearance during the course of this condition.
  1. Massive exudate containing neutrophils, RBCs, and fibrin
  2. Disintegration of RBCs and presence of fibrinosuppurative exudate
  3. Intra-alveolar edema containing few neutrophils and numerous bacteria
  4. Exudates containing granular, semifluid debris which is broken down by macrophages and fibroblasts
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of this patient showing high-grade fever, productive cough, and consolidation of the middle lobe of the right lung on chest x-ray is highly suggestive of lobar pneumonia. The correct sequence of histopathological changes observed during the course of this condition is 3, 1, 2, 4.

Bacterial pneumonia is classified morphologically into lobular pneumonia and lobar pneumonia. Patchy consolidation of the lung is called lobular pneumonia (bronchopneumonia), while consolidation of an entire lobe defines lobar pneumonia.

questions.text: A  59-year old man presented with persistent wheezing, episodes of hemoptysis, and dry cough. Bronchoscopy revealed a mass occluding the left bronchus. Biopsy of the specimen revealed polygonal cells with fine stippled chromatin and eosinophilic cytoplasm arranged in nests. The tumor was positive for CD 56, synaptophysin, and chromogranin. What is the cell of origin of this tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchial carcinoid. Bronchial neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) arise from Kulchitsky cells.

WHO divides neuroendocrine neoplasms into four categories:

  • Typical carcinoid
  • Atypical carcinoid 
  • Large-cell neuroendocrine carcinoma 
  • Small-cell carcinoma 

Carcinoid tumors are low-grade malignant epithelial neoplasms that represent 1% to 5% of all lung tumors. It is not related to smoking. Carcinoids may occur in patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1.

On gross examination, these tumors grow as fingerlike or spherical polypoid masses that project into the lumen of the bronchus or as collar button lesions, penetrating the bronchial wall to fan out in the peribronchial tissue.

Histologically, the tumor is composed of organoid, trabecular, palisading, ribbon, or rosette-like arrangements of cells separated by a delicate fibrovascular stroma. On electron microscopy, the cells exhibit the dense-core neurosecretory granules. 

Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for serotonin, neuron-specific enolase, bombesin, calcitonin, or other peptides.

10% of the cases may produce carcinoid syndrome.

Most carcinoids follow a relatively benign course and have good prognosis.

questions.text: A chronically ill patient is found to have anemia. All the following are true about anemia of chronic disease except:

choices.text: May be seen in association with Hodgkin lymphoma
Interleukin-6 stimulates increase in production of hepcidin in this condition
Low serum ferritin and increased  total iron-binding capacity is seen
Abundant stored iron in tissue macrophages is seen

questions.solution:
Anemia of chronic disease shows high serum ferritin and reduced total iron-binding capacity.

Chronic diseases that produce persistent systemic inflammation can impair red cell production and thus cause anemia of chronic disease. This is due to decreased proliferation of erythroid progenitors and impaired iron utilization.

The chronic illnesses associated with  anemia of chronic disease can be grouped into three categories:

  1. Chronic microbial infections- osteomyelitis, bacterial endocarditis, and lung abscess
  2. Chronic immune disorders- rheumatoid arthritis and regional enteritis
  3. Neoplasms- breast and lung carcinomas, Hodgkin lymphoma

Many effects of inflammation are related to the abnormalities seen in anemia of chronic disease. Inflammatory mediators, like interleukin-6 (IL-6), stimulate the production of hepcidin. Hepcidin inhibits ferroportin in macrophages. This reduces the transfer of iron from the storage pool to the bone marrow, where erythroid precursors are developing. In addition, erythroid progenitors cannot proliferate adequately because erythropoietin levels are inappropriately low for the level of anemia.

Clinical features include mild anemia, with the symptoms of the underlying disease. The red cells may be normocytic and normochromic, or hypochromic and microcytic. Increased storage iron in marrow macrophages, high serum ferritin, and a decreased total iron-binding capacity readily rule out the iron deficiency when the smear shows a microcytic hypochromic picture.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining a specimen from a patient with amyloidosis. When amyloid is stained with Congo red and visualized under ordinary light, which color does it acquire?
questions.solution:
When amyloid is stained with Congo red and is visualized under ordinary light, it shows red colour.

Amyloidosis results from the abnormal folding of proteins, which become insoluble, get aggregated, and are deposited as fibrils in extracellular tissues. Normally, misfolded proteins are degraded. Amyloid may be systemic (generalized), involving several organ systems, or it may be localized to a single organ.

The histologic diagnosis of amyloid is based almost entirely on its staining characteristics:

1. Light microscopy with hematoxylin and eosin stain: Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline substance in extracellular space.

2. Congo red stain: 

  • Under ordinary light, it imparts a pink or red color to tissue deposits.
  • Under the polarizing microscope, it imparts apple-green birefringence to amyloid deposits.

Images below show amyloid stained with congo red stain, under ordinary light, and under polarised light respectively

3. Electron microscopy: All types of amyloid are seen as continuous, nonbranching, nonoriented, thin fibrils

4. X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy: Characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation of amyloid is seen. This conformation is actually responsible for the Congo red staining and birefringence of amyloid.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for autoimmunity in Epstein-Barr virus infection?
questions.solution:
Autoimmunity in Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) infection is the result of polyclonal B cell activation.

Microbes may induce other abnormalities that promote autoimmune reactions. Some viruses, such as EBV and HIV, cause polyclonal B-cell activation, which may result in the production of autoantibodies.

The role of infections in autoimmunity is exemplified by the following:

  1. Molecular mimicry of antigenic cross-reactivity: The structural similarity of the microbial antigens and self-antigens. Rheumatic heart disease is an example in which streptococcal proteins cross-react with myocardial proteins causing myocarditis.
  2. Upregulation of co-stimulatory molecules by infectious organisms.
  3. Polyclonal B cell activation: Caused by EBV and HIV, resulting in the production of autoantibodies.
  4. Alteration of tissue antigens: Infections may alter tissue self-antigens so that they activate T cells and lose the property of self-tolerance.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the hospital after her mother notices red blood in her stool. On examination, you notice mucocutaneous pigmentation around her lip, as shown in the picture below. Radiography with oral contrast reveals multiple, small- to medium-sized polyps in the small intestine. Which type of polyp is most likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features along with the image are suggestive of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Hamartomatous polyps are seen in this condition.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant, hereditary disorder characterized by intestinal hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous dark blue to brown melanin pigmentation, which is particularly evident on the face, buccal mucosa, hands, feet, and perianal and genital regions. This rare syndrome presents at a median age of 11 years. Germline loss of function mutations of STK11 is usually associated with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

The hamartomatous polyps of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome are most common in the small intestine. Grossly, the polyps are large and pedunculated with a lobulated contour. Histologically, they are characterized by an arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by the normal-appearing intestinal epithelium.

Complications:

  • Peutz-Jeghers polyps can cause intussusception, which is occasionally fatal.
  • It is associated with a markedly increased risk of many malignant conditions. Lifetime risk is approximately 40% and regular surveillance is recommended for sex cord tumors of the testes (from birth); gastric and small intestinal cancers (during late childhood); colon, pancreatic, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers (2nd and 3rd decade).

Other options: Hyperplastic polyps, tubular adenoma, and villous adenoma are principally colonic polyps that are derived from the luminal epithelium.

  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man came with complaints of bilateral pedal edema and decreased urine output for the past one month. He has a past history of diabetes mellitus and has not been under regular treatment. The following histopathological image was obtained after a biopsy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows PAS-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis which is seen in diabetic nephropathy.

Nodular glomerulosclerosis, also known as Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesion is a glomerular lesion characterized by spherical-ovoid deposits of a laminated matrix in the periphery of the glomerulus surrounded by patent or dilated capillary loops. These nodules are PAS-positive and usually contain trapped mesangial cells. The nodules often show features of mesangiolysis, defined as disruption of anchoring interactions between the capillaries and the mesangial stalks, which leads to the formation of capillary aneurysms.

Nodular glomerulosclerosis is encountered in approximately 15% to 30% of individuals with long-term diabetes and is a major contributor to renal dysfunction.

The lesions encountered in diabetic nephropathy are:

  • Glomerular lesions: Capillary basement membrane thickening, diffuse mesangial sclerosis, and nodular glomerulosclerosis.
  • Renal vascular lesions, principally arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis.

Other options:

Option B: Crescentic glomerulonephritis is also known as rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). Histopathology will show compressed glomerular tufts by a crescent-shaped mass of epithelial cells and leukocytes.

Option C:  glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is a pattern of immune-mediated injury. MPGN is characterized histologically by changes in the glomerular basement membrane, multiplication of glomerular cells, and the presence of deposits in the mesangial area and glomerular capillaries. The basement membrane shows a 'double-contour' or 'tram-track' appearance on silver or PAS stains. 

Option D: Segmental glomerulosclerosis is characterized by presence of focal and segmental sclerotic lesions of glomeruli which show obliteration of capillary lumens and deposition of plasma proteins along the capillary wall (hyalinosis). On electron microscopy, there is diffuse effacement of foot processes.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the group of chemokines that IL-8 belongs to?

choices.text: They are secreted by activated macrophages
They have 3 amino acids between the two cysteines

questions.solution:
IL­8 is a typical example of the CXC chemokine group. It is secreted by activated macrophages and endothelial cells.

Chemokines are a family of small proteins that act as chemoattractants for specific types of leukocytes. They are classified into four major groups, according to the arrangement of cysteine (C) residues in the proteins:

  • C-X-C chemokines have one amino acid residue separating the first two conserved cysteine residues. They are secreted by activated macrophages, endothelial cells, and other cell types. Their most important inducers are microbial products and other cytokines, mainly IL­1 and TNF. They cause activation and chemotaxis of neutrophils. IL-­8 is typical of this group. 
  • C-C chemokines have the first two conserved cysteine residues adjacent to each other. They mainly act on monocytes, eosinophils, basophils, and lymphocytes, and have fewer actions on neutrophils. Important C-C chemokines are monocyte chemoattractant protein (MCP-1), eotaxin, macrophage inflammatory protein-1α (MIP-1α), etc.
  • C chemokines lack the first and third of the four conserved cysteines. The C chemokines (e.g., lymphotactin) are relatively specific for lymphocytes.
  • CX3C chemokines contain three amino acids between the two cysteines. The only known member of this class is called fractalkine. It acts as a chemoattractant and promotes strong adhesion of monocytes and T cells.

Related Pearl: Various Types of Chemokines Based on their Structure

1.   CXC chemokines (α-chemokines): They have a total of four cysteines, of which the first two separated by one amino acid, represented by 'X'. e.g., interleukin-8 (IL-8/ CXCL8)

2. CC chemokines (β-chemokines): They have a total of four cysteines, of which the first two are adjacent near their amino terminus. e.g., CC chemokine ligands (CCL-1 to 28).

3. C chemokines (γ-chemokines): They have only two cysteines; the first and third of the four cysteines i.e. one N-terminal cysteine and one cysteine downstream. e.g., XCL1 (lymphotactin-α) and XCL2 (lymphotactin-β).

4. CX3C chemokines (d-chemokines): They have three amino acids between two cysteines e.g., fractalkine (or CX3CL1). It acts as a chemoattractant and as an adhesion molecule.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department after suffering severe injuries in a motorcycle accident. His blood pressure was 80/60 mm Hg. Ultrasound examination revealed a ruptured spleen. Arterial blood gas analysis was suggestive of metabolic acidosis. The patient most likely suffered from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The patient most likely suffered from hypovolemic shock due to an internal hemorrhage caused by the ruptured spleen.

Shock is a state of circulatory failure resulting in tissue hypoperfusion and hypoxia. Prolonged shock eventually leads to irreversible tissue damage. Shock progresses through a series of well-defined stages:

  1. Initial nonprogressive stage: Compensatory neurohumoral mechanisms come into play to preserve tissue perfusion.
  2. Progressive stage: Tissue hypoperfusion leads to circulatory and metabolic disturbances. Acidosis occurs due to intracellular anaerobic glycolysis. This causes peripheral pooling, thereby leading to reduced cardiac output and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
  3. Irreversible stage: Tissue injury cannot be reversed even with hemodynamic correction. There is worsening myocardial contractility, renal function impairment, and bacteremia (due to the release of intestinal flora into the circulation).

Hypovolemic shock occurs due to massive hemorrhage or fluid loss from vomiting, diarrhea, and severe burns. This results in low blood volume and cardiac output. Patients present with hypotension, a weak rapid pulse, tachypnea, and cool, clammy, cyanotic skin (due to cutaneous vasoconstriction, which shunts the blood away to vital organs like the heart and brain). More than 90% of otherwise healthy individuals recover with appropriate fluid resuscitation.

Other options:

Option A: Cardiogenic shock occurs due to myocardial pump failure, resulting in low cardiac output. It can be seen in myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, cardiac tamponade, and pulmonary embolism. Patients present with symptoms similar to hypovolemic shock, but treatment outcome is poorer in comparison.

Option B: Septic shock occurs due to systemic infections like bacterial and fungal infections, toxic shock syndrome, pancreatitis, etc, massive trauma, and severe burns, resulting in fatal organ failure. A massive release of inflammatory cytokines causes peripheral vasodilation and pooling, which causes the skin to look flushed. Vascular damage and DIC also occur frequently. Shock lung can be seen due to alveolar damage. Septic shock is also associated with poorer patient outcomes.

Option D: Neurogenic shock occurs due to spinal cord injuries. There is acute vasodilation, which leads to hypotension and tissue hypoperfusion.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman who is a known case of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) presents with severe abdominal pain, hypotension, and decreased level of consciousness. On further examination, colonic artery rupture was discovered. This occurs due to the defects in which type of collagen in EDS?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a typical case of vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) that occurs due to defects in type III collagen.

EDS is a connective tissue disorder occuring due to genetic defects involved in collagen synthesis and action. It is characterized by hyperextensibility of skin, hypermobile joints, easy bruising, and poor wound healing.

The vascular variant of EDS has an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. It was previously known as type IV EDS. It results from defects in type III collagen and occurs due to a mutation in the COL3A1 gene. Unlike other types of EDS, hyperextensibility of skin is absent in the vascular type of EDS. The skin is thin and translucent with visible veins. Other features of vascular EDS include arterial rupture, uterine rupture, bruising, and small joint hyperextensibility.

The collagen defects in other variants of EDS are:

  • Classical EDS: Mutation in the gene encoding type V collagen

questions.text: A 62-year-old lady was planned for coronary angiography through the radial route. The cardiologist had multiple unsuccessful attempts with the radial puncture. As a part of evaluating it, a biopsy of the radial artery was done and is shown below. What is the most probable condition?
questions.solution:
The given condition is Monckeberg's medial sclerosis. The image shows calcification of the walls of the artery seen as the dark purple stained area on H&E staining.

Monckeberg's medial sclerosis or medial calcific sclerosis is a type of arteriosclerosis, characterized by calcification of the walls of muscular arteries, typically involving the internal elastic membrane. The calcifications do not encroach on the lumen and are usually not clinically significant. It is usually an incidental finding. It occurs in people aged 50 years and above as a part of senile degeneration. It is not associated with hypertension or diabetes.

Arteriosclerosis refers to the thickening and loss of elasticity of arterial wall. Other patterns of arteriosclerosis:

  • Arteriolosclerosis: It affects small arteries and arterioles, and may cause downstream ischemic injury. It is associated with hypertension and has two anatomic variants:
    • Hyaline
    • Hyperplastic
  • Atherosclerosis: Most frequent and clinically important pattern which poses a risk of causing coronary, cerebral, and peripheral vascular diseases. It is characterized by the presence of atheromas (also called atheromatous or atherosclerotic plaques) that protrude into vessel lumens.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with acute severe chest pain and shortness of breath. An emergency cardiac catheterization showed occlusion of the anterior descending branch of the left coronary artery. Laboratory reports and ECG support the diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction. Which of the following is the most likely pathological change in the heart muscle after 6 weeks?
questions.solution:
The most likely pathological change in the heart muscle after 6 weeks is a collagen-rich scar. It usually develops 2-8 weeks after myocardial infarction (MI).

The gross and microscopic appearance of the myocardial infarct depends on the duration of survival of the patient following the ischemic injury. Areas of damage undergo a progressive sequence of changes. These include ischemic coagulative necrosis, inflammation, and finally repair with fibrosis. 12 to 24 hours after the MI, it appears reddish-blue due to congestion and extravasated blood.

The sequence of microscopic findings in acute myocardial infarction include:

  • 1-3 days after the occlusion: 
    • Gross: Yellowish-tan infarct center with mottling
    • Microscopic: Signs of coagulative necrosis with nuclear pyknosis, myocyte hypereosinophilia, and marginal contraction band necrosis. It is followed by the loss of nuclei and striations. Myocyte vacuolization is seen at the margins which indicate that the myocytes are viable but poorly contractile.
  • 3-7 days:
    • Gross: Yellowish-tan center softens, and borders become hyperemic
    • Microscopic: Polymorphonuclear leukocytes and macrophages are seen, with the disintegration of dead myofibers, and neutrophils. Phagocytosis of dead cells by macrophages at the infarct border.
  • 7-14 days:
    • Gross: Maximal softening of yellowish-tan area, margins are depressed and reddish-tan to reddish-gray
    • Microscopic: Capillary-rich granulation tissue at the margins, collagen deposition, further phagocytosis of dead material
  • 2- 8 weeks:
    • Gross: Greyish white scar
    • Microscopic: Replacement of the necrotic myocardium with collagen-rich scar tissue from the border to the infarct core. The scar is well developed by the end of the sixth week.

Left anterior descending coronary artery is involved in 40% to 50% cases. The infarct involves the anterior wall of left ventricle near the apex, the anterior portion of ventricular septum and the apex circumferentially.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a history of seizures. Imaging revealed the presence of a tumor in the frontal lobe. Surgery was done, and the biopsy specimen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a frontal lobe tumor, presenting with seizures and the histopathology image showing the ‘fried egg appearance’ of tumor cells, points to the diagnosis of oligodendroglioma.

Oligodendroglioma is a subtype of infiltrating glioma. It is comprised of cells that resemble oligodendrocytes. The tumors are composed of sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. This gives it the ‘fried egg appearance.’ The tumor cells that infiltrate the cortex usually collect around the neuron, and this is known as perineural satellitosis. There is a delicate network of anastomosing thin-walled capillaries between the tumor cells, resembling 'chicken wire.'

Oligodendrogliomas are most commonly detected in the fourth and fifth decades of life. Patients may have had several years of antecedent neurologic complaints, often including seizures. The lesions are found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, mainly in the frontal or temporal lobes. It is treated with a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy. 

Other options:

Option A: Glioblastoma is a synonym for grade IV astrocytoma. Infiltrating astrocytomas and glioblastomas are usually seen in the cerebellum, brainstem, or spinal cord. Histologically, glioblastoma appears like an anaplastic astrocytoma with serpiginous foci of palisading necrosis and microvascular proliferation. 

Option C: Ependymomas in adults occur in the spinal cord and near the ventricles, particularly the fourth ventricle. The microscopic appearance shows both true rosettes and perivascular pseudorosettes.

Option D: Schwannomas are benign tumors often arising directly from peripheral nerves. On microscopy, they are comprised of dense areas called Antoni A areas and loose areas referred to as Antoni B areas. Antoni A areas are eosinophilic and contain spindle cells arranged in intersecting fascicles with nuclear palisading. The central nuclear-free zones are called Verocay bodies. Schwannomas are a component of NF-2.

questions.text: A factory worker at a plastic pipe factory presented with weight loss and abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant for the last 6 months. He had hepatomegaly. CT abdomen revealed that most of the liver was infiltrated by contrast-enhanced mass and the presence of thorium was detected. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of the factory worker with upper quadrant abdominal pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and the CT inference suggest angiosarcoma of the liver.

Angiosarcoma of the liver is usually seen in individuals having occupational exposure to agents such as vinyl chloride, arsenic, or thorotrast. The gross specimen of the liver shows greyish-white lesions, with multiple reddish-brown hemorrhagic foci and several blood-filled spaces. CT is the preferred investigation and it reveals infiltrating contrast-enhanced mass diffusely spread over the liver. Thorium is picked up in the CT due to the presence of heterogeneously enhanced attenuation in the liver, perihepatic area, and spleen.

Option A: Cavernous hemangiomas appear as red-blue, soft nodules, usually less than 2 cm in diameter. Their clinical significance is that they might be mistaken radiographically or intraoperatively for metastatic tumors. Peripheral filling at the delayed phase of the contrast administration is a typical finding in this condition as the tumor is more in the periphery of the liver.

Option B: Metastatic tumor of the liver can be differentiated from primary HCC on a CECT. There is no enhancement or enhancement less than the surrounding liver following contrast.

Option D: Primary hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has a delayed arterial filling phase and washes out rapidly in a CECT. It also shows a wedge-shaped perfusion abnormality in the CT due to arterioportal shunts.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with body pain and easy fatigability. Investigations revealed a hemoglobin level of 7 gm/dL.  The peripheral smear revealed macrocytic hypochromic cells and hypersegmented neutrophils. Further investigations revealed elevated serum levels of homocysteine and methylmalonic acid. This condition may also lead to?

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord

questions.solution:
The given scenario describes megaloblastic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 deficiency may lead to subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord. 

Megaloblastic anemia can be due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency. In vitamin B12 deficiency, serum levels of both homocysteine and methylmalonic acid are elevated whereas, in folate deficiency, only homocysteine levels are elevated.

Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord occurs due to defective myelin synthesis which leads to degeneration of the ascending and descending spinal tracts. It presents with symmetrical paraesthesia and progresses to weakness, ataxia, and spasticity. Complications include complete paraplegia. It can be treated by the administration of vitamin B12. 

Other options:

Option A- Syringomyelia is characterized by the formation of a fluid-filled cavity in the spinal cord. It is associated with Chiari I malformation. It leads to progressive myelopathy and presents with loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper limbs.

Option B- Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is an encephalitis caused when JC polyomavirus infects the oligodendrocytes and leads to demyelination. It usually occurs in immunocompromised individuals. The patients develop focal and progressive neurological symptoms.

Option D- Central pontine myelinolysis occurs due to the loss of myelin in the base of the pons. It occurs after rapid correction of hyponatremia.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman gives birth to an infant with less than 5th percentile length. The head and torso are of normal size but extremities are short. The head circumference is at the 95th percentile, and frontal bossing is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This given clinical scenario is suggestive of achondroplasia.

Achondroplasia is the most common skeletal dysplasia and a major cause of dwarfism. It has autosomal dominant inheritance.

It occurs due to the gain of mutation in fibroblast growth factor receptor (FGFR3). This leads to abnormal cartilage proliferation at growth plates and affects endochondral bone growth. Infants present with:

  • Short stature
  • Rhizomelic shortening of limbs
  • Frontal bossing
  • Midface deficiency

The condition is not associated with changes in longevity, intelligence, or reproductive status.
