questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with watery diarrhea associated with frequent epigastric pain, bloating, and indigestion for the past few weeks that did not respond to medications. Stool culture is negative. His lab reports show microcytic hypochromic anemia and serum K+ 2.9 mmol/L. Upper GI endoscopy is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes watery diarrhea, hypokalemia (serum K+<3.5 mM), and symptoms of achlorhydria (bloating, indigestion, iron deficiency) which suggests the diagnosis of WDHA syndrome caused by VIPoma.

VIPoma is pancreatic endocrine neoplasia. The tumor secretes vasoactive intestinal peptides which are responsible for the secretory watery diarrhea and other symptoms mentioned above. While suspecting a case of VIPoma it is essential to conduct a VIP assay so as to confirm the presence of other tumors of neural crest origin such as neuroblastoma or pheochromocytoma. 

Diagnosis can be made by the demonstration of an elevated plasma VIP level and the history of large-volume diarrhea.

Other options: 

Option A: Gastrinoma is a neuroendocrinal tumor characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in gastrointestinal tract ulcers. The most common presentations of gastrinoma are epigastric pain, diarrhea, and peptic ulcers. The ulcers occur at typical locations (proximal duodenum) and atypical locations (distal duodenum, jejunum). However, in this scenario, the endoscopy findings were normal.

Option C: Delta cell tumor, aka somatostatinoma, is also a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor presents with cholelithiasis, diarrhea, neurofibromatosis.

Option D: Pancreatic carcinoid is associated with excess serotonin and presents with sweating, flushing, diarrhea, and edema.

questions.text: Choose the correct pedigree chart for autosomal dominant inheritance:
questions.solution:
Among the given pedigrees, 'chart 1' is representative of an autosomal dominant type of inheritance.

In the autosomal dominant chart, we see that at least one parent of the index case is usually affected. It is manifested in the heterozygous state. When an affected person marries an unaffected one, there is a one in two chance of being affected by the disease. 

It is also seen that both males and females are affected by autosomal dominant inheritance patterns. Also, both males and females can transmit the condition.

The following flow chart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree chart.

 

Option B shows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. It is seen that the parents of the affected individual are usually not affected and there is a one in four chance of being affected by the trait, among the siblings. 

Option C shows the X-dominant pattern of inheritance. This pattern of inheritance is caused by dominant alleles on the X chromosome. It is seen that an affected female parent transmits the disease to half her sons and half her daughters. An affected male parent with an unaffected female transmits it to all his daughters. None of his sons will be affected.

Option D shows the X-linked recessive pattern. Mutated genes on the X chromosome do not have corresponding alleles on the Y chromosome. Thus, males are hemizygous for X-linked mutant genes, and they express these disorders. A heterozygous female may express the disorder partially or may be a carrier.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman, previously diagnosed with breast cancer, is now found to have endometrial cancer. Genetic testing revealed a mutation in the PTEN gene. What other condition is she at increased risk of developing?
questions.solution:
A patient with a PTEN germline mutation with history of breast carcinoma, now diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma is at high risk of developing thyroid carcinoma concerning cowden syndrome.

Cowden syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder associated with pTEN germline mutations and marked by:

  • Hamartomatous growths of the skin and mucus membranes- buccal, intestinal, and colonic
  • Increased incidence of epithelial cancers particularly of the breast, endometrium, and thyroid

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who was a known case of alcoholic liver disease came with complaints of fever, abdominal discomfort and distension, and fatigue. On local examination of the abdomen, shifting dullness was present and the fluid thrill test was found to be positive. Which of the following decreases in the above-mentioned condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts worsening of liver disease causing ascites which leads to hypoalbuminemia (decrease in albumin). The history of fever can most likely point toward bacterial peritonitis which is an important complication of end-stage liver disease. 

Acute-phase reactants are plasma proteins whose concentrations increase or decrease in the serum during inflammation. They are synthesized in the liver. The synthesis is mainly stimulated by cytokines like IL-6, IL-1 and TNF. 

Albumin is a negative acute-phase reactant that decreases during an inflammatory process. There is a shift of albumin from the intravascular compartment to the extravascular compartment due to increased oncotic pressure and decreased hydrostatic pressure. 

Other negative acute-phase reactants:

  • Transferrin
  • Retinol-binding protein
  • Antithrombin

Other options:

Options B, C, and D: Fibrinogen, SAA, and CRP are positive acute phase reactants that increase during an inflammatory process.

Other positive acute-phase reactants include:

  • Procalcitonin
  • Ferritin
  • Hepcidin
  • Thrombopoietin

questions.text:
A patient was tested for CFTR gene mutations and was found to be positive. Which of the following features can be seen in a patient with CFTR gene mutation?
  1. Morphologically abnormal sweat glands
  2. Squamous metaplasia of pancreas
  3. Congenital bilateral absence of vas deferens
  4. Focal biliary cirrhosis
questions.solution:
CFTR gene mutations result in cystic fibrosis. In all variants of cystic fibrosis, the sweat glands are morphologically unaffected.

Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal reccessive disorder of ion transport that affects fluid secretion in exocrine glands and in the epithelial lining. It is caused primarily due to a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene which serves as an anion channel in the apical membranes of epithelial cells. This leads to abnormally viscous secretions that obstruct organ passages, resulting in recurrent infections, pancreatic insufficiency, steatorrhea, malnutrition, hepatic cirrhosis, intestinal obstruction, and male infertility.

Impaired fat absorption due to the loss of pancreatic exocrine secretion and the resultant avitaminosis A can contribute to squamous metaplasia of the lining epithelium of the pancreas. Associated squamous metaplasia of the salivary gland may also be found.

Focal biliary cirrhosis may occur, which may progress to involve the whole liver, resulting in diffuse hepatic nodularity.

Azoospermia and infertility are seen in most male patients. Congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens is commonly seen in these patients. In some patients, bilateral absence of the vas deferens may be the only feature suggesting an underlying CFTR mutation.
